quizzes.question: A Boolean can be (choose two):
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Booleans[/h1]

In Ruby, there are two Boolean values: [b]true [/b]and [b]false[/b]. [code format="rb" ]isOnline = true

userIsAdmin = false[/code]
[note]Another value that you will often encounter is [b]nil[/b]. It shows the absence of value.[/note]

quizzes.question: As a Boolean, the string "false" is:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Booleans[/h1]

If you try to evaluate a value other than [b]true [/b]or [b]false [/b]as a Boolean, Ruby will automatically treat it as a Boolean. 
When this is done, a non-Boolean value that evaluates to true is called "[b]truthy[/b]" and a non-Boolean value that evaluates to false is called "[b]falsey[/b]".

In Ruby only [b]false [/b]and [b]nil [/b]are falsey. Everything else is truthy (even 0 is truthy).
[note]Only [b]true [/b]and [b]false [/b]are Booleans. [b]nil [/b]is not a Boolean. 0 is not a Boolean. The string "Hello" is not a Boolean. However, in a context where a Boolean is expected, Ruby evaluates them as Boolean ([b]truthy [/b]and [b]falsey[/b]).[/note]
